title: Do you think the three WoO 47 sonatas by Beethoven should be included with the 32 piano sonatas or should they be treated as part of his smaller 'Klavierstücke'? - Quora

response.answer_text: This image, released in 2019, was taken in April 2017, but processing the data took some time (source: NASA/JPL Edu):  It’s an image of a black hole’s silhouette: M87*, located at the center of the gargantuan elliptical galaxy Messier 87, or M87, 53 million light-years (318 quintillion miles) away. It was, it is a huge achievement. Yet many people were disappointed. They compared this image to artists’ renderings and Interstellar’s CGI, totally missing the point.  Beethoven’s Kurfürstensonaten are in a somewhat similar situation. Many people, including some professional musicians, are dismissing them as “juvenile”, “lacking a distinct musical identity”… I think that they are missing the point. Yes, they are blurry images; but the blurry images of Beethoven’s later sonatas. And they are not as blurry as the image of M87*. You can hear the echoes of the style of C. P. E. Bach in them, but also the foreshadowing of Beethoven’s later works. There is a bit of awkwardness in some of the transitions, and the ornamentation is a bit excessive; but get over these, and you can catch a prevision of the Pathétique, and nab methods and building blocks of his symphonies, decades before he wrote them. If pianists like Mikhail Pletnev, Emil Gilels, Jandó Jenő, Jörg Demus, Ronald Brautigam, Ulrich Stærk, and probably many others deemed these sonatas worthy to be played in recitals and/or recorded alongside Beethoven’s other sonatas, who am I to argue with them? Just kidding, I love to contradict famous people; but in this case I happen to agree with those who believe that these works belong with the rest of Beethoven’s sonatas. The current practice of treating them as “lesser works” is hardly justifiable. Compare these works and the Opus 49, then compare the Opus 49 and the Hammerklavier. If we leave these out, maybe we should leave out the Opus 49 too. But if you ask me, Beethoven wrote 35 sonatas.

Oho! I was unaware of WoO 47! I thought you might have been thinking of the two Op 49 teaching sonatas! I’m only now reading through them! I suppose, it doesn’t matter one way or another to me whether they’re included in with his other sonatas—in what sense do you mean “included with?” I’d include them in an edition of his sonatas, if I were a publisher and I thought that people would be interested in them, I suppose. He didn’t want to publish Op 49, I did read somewhere, but, they were obtained and published anyhow. Did he write anything, or is anything reported that he said about whether those early sonatas were things he absolutely didn’t want published? A moot point, by this time, isn’t it?

They belong with other juvenile works of his - they are more for curiosity’s sake. And just for sheer completeness. If he had considered them worthy of being included with his published, numbered works, he would have included them. My guess is that he would be absolutely horrified that they are being played at all. I think it’s fine to play them out of curiosity, but I wouldn’t publish them along with the 32 unless it’s a complete works edition where you are including absolutely everything. And then in a separate volume. It’s hard to know where to stop with a composer - should we perform everything, even the pieces they wrote at the age of 6? In his teens, Beethoven wrote a trio for flute, bassoon and piano. We bassoonists don’t have a lot of chamber music (by Beethoven or anyone else), so it’s very tempting to play it and many people do. But I just can’t bring myself to do it - it’s mediocre at best, is not gratifying to play (it’s very badly written for the instrument) and I can’t help feeling he would have been very unhappy to know that future generations had gotten their hands on it. Then there is Brahms, who burnt all of his early works that didn’t meet his standards - not just juvenalia but works he wrote as an adult. That seems a shame.

Beethoven was very picky when he composed. An opus number was Beethoven’s own stamp of approval. Even his most iconic piece “Für Elise” is part of the Works Without a Opus Number. Even his earliest Piano Concerto, numbered 0, is also part of the WoO. Even though it is pleasure to play, it is not on the standard of the other 5 (6 if you count the transcribed Violin Concerto). So by going with Beethoven standards… no, these pieces should not be included in the 32 piano sonatas.

It's a difficult one because a number of works exist in musical literature that are categorised separately from a similar corpus in the same composer's oeuvre. Just one example: I spoke to a friend about the evolution of Tchaikovsky's style throughout his seven symphonies. I was corrected that Tchaikovsky wrote six (because he was unaware of "Manfred”). In Beethoven's case, the three WoO 47 sonatas are juvenile works without opus number. Purely personally, I would accord them a status similar to the The “Trois nouvelles études" of Chopin, which are relegated to the back of his op 10 and 25 sets.

L v. B. took conscious, deliberate control over the publication of his works and which opus numbers he chose for them. he himself probably didn’t consider the juvenile compositions in the same category of those he enumerated, and who are we to impose our categories, clerks ?
l would say that they are part of the Klavierstücke, because Beethoven is known to have considered them as such, attempts in getting better at his compositional technic.
There is a simple solution—leave them be. My opinion doesn’t matter a whit. Only Beethoven’s does.
